courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Public Relations and Social Theory
courses.description: Public relations is often studied and researched from marketing, business, communication management and functionalism perspectives. However, these perspectives do not suffice to understand its role in building, or destroying, trust, social legitimacy and reputation in the era of social media in which a ruthless comment, a 140-word microblog or a casual choice of words might trigger public reprimands and boycotts. As such, public relations should also be examined as a social phenomenon as well as a social activity in its own right and with its societal context. A more extensive use of social theories could help to provide analytical frameworks that highlight the consequences of public relations have for other actors and society as a whole. By applying the work of a group of prominent social theorists including Jürgen Habermas, Niklas Luhmann, Michel Foucault, etc, insights can be garnered for public relations studies at the macro, meso, and micro levels. Issues of how social power, behavior, and language exchanged or negotiated among various social actors in public relations phenomena will be intensively discussed in this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the conclusion of the course, students should have developed a deeper understanding and enhanced appreciation of social theories that could be brought to integrate in their daily practices. In particular, students are expected to have attained the following knowledge by the end of the course:

● A solid theoretical understanding of some of the classic social theories, including the key figures, concepts and developments.

● Application of theoretical perspectives to examining the public relations cases as social phenomena and social activities.

● Extended thinking ability as to how social theories could be applied to provide a constructive direction in the real practice of public relations in times of normalcy and crisis.

● Professional ethics and social legitimacy paradigm conducive to communicating messages to various actors in the society

● Commitment and passion towards professional development, intellectual curiosity and life-long learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
(For reference only, subject to change)

The following topics will be covered by the course:

Introduction and an Overview of Public Relations

The Current Challenging Public Spheres for Public Relations

Legitimacy and Legitimation in Public Relations

The Framing and Reframing Battles

Public Relations and Quests for Responsibility

Community and Social Capital to Public Relations

Social Constructionist Perspective on Crisis Communication

Radical Pluralism and Public Relations

Stakeholder Theory and Mapping

Message House Crafting

Corporate Social Responsibility and Sustainability

Corporate Reputation in Crisis

Issues Management

Media Management

Corporate Reputation Management Plan--COOTSO

courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Media Investment and Performance Marketing
courses.description: The world of advertising is rapidly evolving, providing brands with new opportunities to reach their customers more precisely, manage their campaigns more effectively, and track the outcome of their advertising investment more transparently. This shift highlights the need for marketers and media practitioners to better understand "Performance Marketing" and develop the right strategies and tactics to implement advertising campaigns and determine the return on investment. By doing so, they can enjoy a more efficient use of their advertising budget and ultimately make every advertising dollar count. To navigate this changing landscape, the course aims to equip students with the knowledge and skills needed on audience planning and consumer journey understanding, latest advertising data and technology as well as performance advertising planning and activation principles, which all in all aid brands to optimize their advertising outcomes and drive business growth as a result.

Design an outcome driven advertising media strategy

2. Manage the expected outcome of a media plan

Week 7 Driving advertising media outcome (I) Power of data & technology

1. Harness data & technology in advertising

2. Data ethics and future

Week 8 Driving advertising media outcome (II) Power of data analytics

1. Audience analytics in optimizing media planning

2. Campaign analytics in optimizing media performance

Week 9 Final project (I) Project briefing

Power of creativity

courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Public Relations for Entrepreneurs
courses.description: This course aims to equip students with the knowledge and skills necessary for success in both entrepreneurship and public relations. By exploring the principles and practices of public relations within the context of start-ups and small businesses, students will develop a deeper understanding of the crucial role effective communication plays in achieving business objectives.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:

1. Establish a solid foundation in the principles and practices of public relations for entrepreneurs, applying these skills in various contexts.
2. Develop and implement effective PR strategies that align with a company's overall strategy and objectives.
3. Analyze case studies of successful start-ups and small businesses to identify the PR strategies that contributed to their achievements.
4. Manage media relations effectively, respond to crises, and leverage social media to enhance brand awareness and engagement.
5. Prepare for careers in public relations for start-ups and small businesses, or for launching their own ventures and managing their own PR efforts.

courses.description: This course will study public relations as a management function in strategic communication that applies communication, organization, and management theories to the research, planning, execution, and evaluation of the public relations programs of organizations. The case study approach is adopted to allow students to develop the competence of logical thinking and critical analysis in a wide variety of issues, which include marketing public relations, corporate social responsibility, crisis communication, image restoration, reputation management, relationship management, public affairs, and issue management. Students will be able to conduct situation analysis and formulate strategies and tactics to achieve various public relations goals of the organization after completing the course.

1. Understand a public relations campaign skeleton and key elements;
2. Utilize the theoretical knowledge to develop a complete strategic public relations campaign; and
3. Acquire problem-solving skills and critical thinking ability in various public relations issues and practices.

courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Film Directors
courses.description: This course will explore the "auteur" or "author" theory by focusing on several directors each time the course is offered. Auteur directors such as Alfred Hitchcock (希治閣), John Ford (約翰福特), Billy Wilder (比利懷德), Charlie Chaplin (卓別林), Akira Kurosawa (黑澤明), Francis Ford Coppola (哥普拉), Orson Welles (奧信威爾斯), Martin Scorcese (史高西斯), Zhang Yimou (張藝謀), Stanley Kwan (關錦鵬), Ann Hui (許鞍華),Wong Kar Wai (王家衛), Woody Allen (活地亞倫), Fellini (費里尼), Ingmar Bergman (柏格曼), Stanley Kubrick (寇比力克), Lars von Trier (查艾爾), etc., are among the possible choices for study in this course. Each semester the selection of directors will ensure a mix of past and present, as well as American, European and Asian filmmakers.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to:

1. Have deep understanding of the directors of the director’s key hole in filmmaking.

2. Acquire analytical skills to critique a film aesthetically and thematically through the prism of a director's vision.
courses.course_syllabus:
(For reference only, subject to changes)

1. Introduction to Course/ The Hollywood System/Auteur Theory

2. Video: 100 Years of American Cinema

3. Classic Hollywood Directors/ Hitchcock

4. Alfred Hitchcock Film Viewing

5. Hollywood Maverick/ Kubrick

6. Kubrick Film Viewing

7. Independent Auteurs/ Coen Brothers

8. Coen Brothers Film Viewing

9. Emerging Auteur/ Christopher Nolan

10. Christopher Nolan Film Viewing

courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Cultural Studies and Popular Culture
courses.description: Popular culture circulates popular images, encourages communal identities and articulates social divisions. This course will examine the social implications of popular culture by concepts and methods developed by cultural studies theoriests. Cultural studies is the study of meaning and power. The course will introduce to students leading thinkers, concepts and tools in the emerging field and encourage students to assess the consumption of popular culture in their daily life.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to:

1. Understand the cultural logic of political economy behind the production of popular culture.

2. Understand the interplay between the daily consumption of cultural product and the changing social order, in terms of both local and global scale

courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil Communication or PhD Communication
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should gain a clear understanding of the following:
• The logic of social scientific research in communication;
• Methods of framing research questions and techniques of gathering and interpreting empirical observations in an effort to answer a wide range of research questions; and
• The boundaries of the scientific approach to knowledge, the limits of quantitative methods in general, their techniques, assumptions, the strengths and weaknesses of particular methods and critiques of specific design.
Students should become more critical and discerning in their consumption of research findings; and are able to make appropriate problem/method(s) linkage in real-world settings.

Special emphasis will be given to how culture is communicated and interpreted by persons of diverse backgrounds. The course will explore a variety of communication issues pertinent to professional and organizational life. Topics include ethnic and gender-based cultural differences within organizations, cultural issues in the global marketplace, relationships between national and organizational cultures, corporate culture and discourse in intercultural settings, global team leadership and intercultural negotiation.

courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Advanced Statistical Analysis in Communication
courses.description: This course introduces common multivariate techniques, logics, methods and their applications in communication and social sciences. Students are expected to understand various assumptions of and rationalities behind various statistical methods, learn the techniques and uses, and apply them to their own research. The course aims at strengthening students' ability in formulating research questions, validating theories and applying appropriate methodologies, regardless of what research directions (quantitative of qualitative) they are interested in.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil Communication or PhD Communication
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should gain a clear understanding of the concepts and techniques of multivariate data analysis. Students should be able to:
• Determine which multivariate technique is appropriate for a specific research problem;
• Use SPSS to perform various multivariate statistical analyses; and
• Perform and interpret various multivariate statistical tests including scale construction, factor analysis, multiple regression, MANOVA, discriminant analysis, logistic regression, path analysis and structural equation modeling.

courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Digital Research
courses.description: How has the rise of digital media, new data landscape, and computational tools transformed the process of knowledge generation and academic production? In preparing students to engage with this digital social and research environment, this course has three interrelated foci: (1) To introduce epistemological and ontological perspectives on the concepts of data, analytics, and knowledge production; (2) To discuss emerging theoretical approaches to studying digital media-rich phenomenon; (3) To provide basic training on selecting digital data analytic tools and techniques, with an aim to incorporate these skills in research projects.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Communication; or MPhil Communication
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
- Understand the key notions of “data,” “digital media” and “digitization” at a theoretical and epistemological level
- Know how the computer works and understand the popular algorithms for social sciences
- Conceive and design digital research projects from a communication studies or broadly defined social science perspective
- Understand the applicability and limitations of conventional research methods in the digital arena.
- Take up basic ideas and skills of digital research such as data mining and data visualization.
courses.course_syllabus:
(For reference only, subject to change.)
The following topics will be covered by the course:
- Conceptualization of “data” and “digital media”
- Data and surveillance
- Big data analytics
- Online ethnography
- Methods of data mining
- Methods of data visualization
- Online experiment
- Ethics of big data
- Critical data and algorithm studies

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.description: Students concentrate their reading and study of one particular topic in Journalism of their interests under the supervision of a faculty member. Students are required to submit a paper at the end of the course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Journalism
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students engage in either a journalistic project or an academic project. In the former case, the students should plan, develop, and execute a piece of in-depth feature coverage of a chosen topic under the supervision of a teacher. In the latter case, the students should plan, design, and execute an academic study on a topic related to journalism under the supervision of a faculty member. Students are required to submit a substantial journalistic report in the former case and a paper in the latter case at the end of the course.

The students are expected to acquire critical thinking and analytical ability; gain the experience of engaging in a long-term journalistic project or an academic research project; gain an in-depth understanding on a special topic (a public affairs topic in the case of a journalistic project and an academic topic within the field of journalism studies in the case of an academic project).

courses.subject: COMM
courses.title: Brand Strategy and Integrated Marketing Communication
courses.description: With a business and competitive landscape complicated by social challenges, media fragmentation, new technologies, and polarized consumer opinions, brands must keep abreast of the fast-changing environment to have relevant presence and behaviour. It is important to have a brand strategy that truly connects and has the potential to create behavioural changes. This course puts focus back on the basics, and align with the students on some of the core concepts on marketing communications, before developing any integrated marketing campaign that would otherwise become just a blinkered approach to multifaceted problems.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For Students of M.S.Sc. in Advertising and M.S.Sc. in Corporate Communication
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will learn to develop brand strategy with sharpness by asking the right questions, investigating new perspectives, and define what we want people to do, before we are over excited with various tactics and rush to put together campaign. We develop works that work, and not noise in the market.
